lessons.title: First Greetings
lessons.goal: Politely greet an adult stranger and respond to "How are you?"
lessons.grammarFocus: Singular vs plural of respect (-i suffix)
cultureNotes: Importance of first greetings and response etiquette in Shona culture

activities.description: Mimic-the-audio chant: Learners repeat recorded greetings after native speaker.
Dialogue scramble – arrange shuffled greeting phrases in correct order.
Pair practice: introduce yourself to a virtual character using proper greeting formality.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction. Automatic speech evaluation checks for correct greeting form and pronunciation.

exercises.question: Which greeting is appropriate for addressing an elder?

lessons.title: Introducing Yourself
lessons.goal: State your name and where you are from.
lessons.grammarFocus: Subject prefix ndi- (I), phrases 'Zita rangu ndi…' and 'Ndinonzi…', preposition 'ku' for origin.
cultureNotes: When introducing yourself to elders, add a respectful plural form when addressing them.
Handshakes are light; clapping once before speaking shows politeness.

activities.description: Audio echo: repeat full introduction sentences after native speaker.
Drag-and-drop jigsaw: build the sentence 'Zita rangu ndi ___' from word blocks.
Meet-and-greet: record a short intro including name & hometown; the AI avatar replies.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction; speech evaluation checks correct structure and pronunciation.

exercises.question: How do you say 'My name is…' in Shona?
Which word in Shona means 'I am called'?

lessons.title: Farewells & Small Talk
lessons.goal: End a conversation politely and perform basic leave-takings.
lessons.grammarFocus: Plural forms for respect and future tense marker 'ticha-' in 'tichasangana'.
cultureNotes: 'Sarayi zvakanaka' is used when the other person is staying; 'Fambai zvakanaka' when they are leaving.
It is common to clap lightly once or twice while saying farewell to an elder.

activities.description: Match Shona farewells to their English meanings.
Simulated good-bye conversation choosing correct phrases for given context.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice quiz on selecting correct farewell based on scenario.

exercises.question: Which phrase means 'We will meet again'?

lessons.title: Checkpoint Challenge: Café Line-up
lessons.goal: Apply greetings, introductions and farewells in a timed café scenario.
lessons.grammarFocus: Consolidation of plural respectful forms and introduction phrases.
cultureNotes: Politeness is key when ordering; greet before requesting service.
Queue etiquette: allow elders to go first if possible.

activities.description: Interactive café queue: choose correct greeting, introduce yourself to barista, end with proper farewell.

lessons.assessment: Scenario score: must reach 80% correct selections within time limit to pass.

exercises.question: Match each Shona phrase to its English meaning.
Which greeting should you use for a group of elders?

lessons.title: This Morning – Recent Past
lessons.goal: Narrate morning activities that happened today using the recent-past marker -a-.
lessons.grammarFocus: Recent past tense (-a-) vs habitual (-no-): Ndakamuka vs Ndinomuka.
cultureNotes: Shona distinguishes between actions that happened today (recent past) and yesterday (remote past).

activities.description: Picture sequence – drag verbs to match a cartoon of morning routine.
Swap subject prefixes to practise person + -a- forms.
Learner records three sentences about their morning in recent past.

lessons.assessment: Auto-graded spoken diary must use at least two correct -a- verbs.

exercises.question: Select the recent-past form for 'I washed' (kugeza).
Translate to Shona: I got dressed.

lessons.title: Yesterday – Remote Past
lessons.goal: Contrast yesterday's events using the remote-past marker -ka-.
lessons.grammarFocus: Remote past (-ka-) for actions before today; time adverbs nezuro (yesterday).
cultureNotes: Learners appreciate the nuanced time frame encoded in Shona past tenses.

lessons.title: Connecting Events – Sequence Words
lessons.goal: Use connectors wobva (then) and pakati (while) to chain events.
cultureNotes: Storytelling in Shona relies heavily on connectors to maintain flow.

activities.description: Order mixed sentences into a coherent paragraph.
Roll icons, compose a 4-sentence story using at least two connectors.

lessons.assessment: Short written story graded for connector accuracy.

exercises.question: Translate: After that I went to work.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Audio Diary
lessons.goal: Record a 60-second diary contrasting today vs yesterday.
lessons.grammarFocus: Assessment of recent vs remote past and connectors.

activities.description: Learner speaks; AI transcribes and highlights tense errors.
Replay annotated transcript and correct mistakes.

lessons.assessment: Must hit 80% tense accuracy to pass.

exercises.question: Which tense describes something that happened this morning?
Which word best links two actions in sequence?
